Before you begin

  • This online form can take an hour or more to complete.
  • You can apply yourself. You can also ask a friend or lawyer to apply on your behalf. In some situations, the police may apply for you.
  • You may find answering the questions in this online form difficult. We will ask questions about your situation, including what happened, when, and what protection you think you need.
  • After completing this online form you will have the necessary forms (possibly 2 or 3) to take to court.
  • Once you lodge the forms at court, the person you are wanting protection from will get a copy of your application.

Going to court

  • You need to lodge the forms and all attachments at a magistrates court. You can do this yourself, or you can ask a friend or family member to do so on your behalf.
  • You will be given a date to appear in court (usually in about 4 weeks time).
  • Your court date can be sooner if you also ask for an urgent temporary protection order. You have to explain why you need this.
  • The respondent will be given a copy of the application which includes a notice to appear in court at the same time.

Start preparing your application

  1. Do you need legal advice? You may wish to get legal advice before or after preparing your forms to get a protection order.
    • You can talk to a lawyer about your application before or after you lodge it with the court.

How can I get legal advice?

You can get legal advice from:

  • Legal Aid Queensland—call 1300 65 11 88 for free legal advice
  • community legal centres—visit www.qails.org.au or www.legalaid.qld.gov.au, or call Legal Aid Queensland on 1300 65 11 88 to find a centre in your area
  • private solicitors—visit www.qls.com.au or call the Queensland Law Society on 1300 367 757 for names of solicitors who can help you
  • prevention programs and application assistance programs—in some areas there are programs that can advise you, you can ask about these programs at a magistrates court.
